resource.chars:
20. 
With practical knowledge of this instrument 
I can assert that under Antarctic conditions any observer 
would have been glad to secure his anemometer to a post 
and equally glad to obtain even a maximum and a minimum 
reading of a fluid surface travelling irregularly and 
incessantly over a minute scale. It is further to be 
noted that notwithstanding his criticism of the method 
of exposure Mr Curtis is obliged to own that the 'means' 
are in very close accord with the cup anemometer. 
Here, as so often in this volume, purely 
theoretic criticism is offered without regard to the 
very exceptional practical experience involved. 
To Mr Curtis' remarks on Pages 488, 489, 490 I 
have already referred, they are concerned in proving the 
prevalence of Easterly winds in our region, they omit to 
record evidence which might shake this theory and finally 
they unwarrantably reverse the directions of the winds 
as observed on Lieutenant Royds' journey. 
The remarks on page 491, 492 are of a similar 
nature. Here for the same reason he is desirous of 
proving a high pressure to the South. 
He selects Lieutenant Royds' journey to 
obtain indications of a rise of level on the Barrier 
Surface, notwithstanding that the track of the journey, 
as will be seen on the general chart, forms an acute 
angle with the sea face of the Barrier. 
<u>He<\u>
